In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This technical assistance (TA) project will support enhanced safeguards management in 
two key federal agencies—the National Highways Authority (NHA) and the Water and Power 
Development Authority (WAPDA).1 Both authorities implement major greenfield projects that 
result in significant land acquisition and resettlement impacts. The Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  approved  its  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009). Both  the  NHA  and  WAPDA  have 
environment and social units; however, the NHA has no resettlement or social specialists in the 
unit. The WAPDA’s Land Acquisition and Resettlement Unit (LARU) is relatively new, having 
been established in 2010, and has yet to recruit a resettlement specialist. 
 
2.  The TA will focus on improving institutional safeguards management to address internal 
capacity  constraints  and  providing  legal  advice,  interpretation,  and  recommendations  on 
applicable  national  and  provincial  laws  to  address  resettlement-related  issues  in  the  NHA 
(regarding transport) and the WAPDA (regarding water and power development). The NHA and 
WAPDA will be the executing agencies for the TA. Each agency will appoint a qualified director 
for resettlement prior to TA implementation. The Government of Pakistan concurred with the TA 
and ADB fielded a mission to discuss TA activities with the NHA and WAPDA. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The absence of a national or provincial policy on resettlement in Pakistan results in 
displacement and compensation issues being addressed in an ad hoc manner with a high risk of 
impoverishment to those affected. Typically, internally financed projects suffer from insufficient 
compensation  to  replace  lost  assets,  delayed  payments,  insufficient  planning  for  livelihood 
restoration, social and cultural disarticulation, exclusion of untitled persons from development 
support, and lack of attention to gender and vulnerable groups. No relevant requirements for 
involuntary  resettlement  exist  within  government  systems.  A  resettlement  ordinance  was 
prepared under ADB regional TA,2 however it was not passed by the legislature. National and 
provincial commitment is required to pass a resettlement act and/or revise provincial legislation 
to enable laws to be more responsive to Pakistan's development needs. Improvements to reflect 
international best practice standards are essential if Pakistan is to obtain external financing of 
the public or private sector. Under ongoing regional TA,3 ADB is working with the board of 
revenue  (BOR)  of  Punjab  province  to  streamline  land  acquisition  procedures  and  provide 
capacity  development  to  key  executing  agencies.  Overhauling  a  disparate  system  of  land 
administration  and  acquisition  that  has  changed  little  since  colonial  times  is  a  long-term 
undertaking. There is no uniform national approach or system; issues in each province have to 
be addressed separately. 
 
4.  Pakistan is one of ADB’s major partners. ADB’s active portfolio in Pakistan consists of 
19 projects with an approved amount of $3.5 billion. During 2007-2011, the annual average 
contract award in Pakistan has been around $1.1 billion and disbursement achievement around

Manila (TA 5935-REG, approved in September, for $500,000). 
3  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Mainstreaming Land Acquisition and Resettlement Safeguards in Central and

2 
$1.0 billion.4 ADB has a relatively young portfolio with many greenfield projects with a strong 
focus on energy and transport which require substantial safeguards work. The absence of a 
regulatory framework, and outdated systems coupled with limited technical capacity, is the 
principal challenge facing effective resettlement management in Pakistan.5 
 
5.  Project preparation. Considerable up front work needs to be undertaken to address 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. The Planning Commission’s documents required for project 
approval (PC-1 and PC-2) often  underestimate costs of land acquisition and resettlement, 
including safeguard staff in project management units. Social safeguards are viewed primarily 
as a requirement of international financial institutions and bilateral donors, which the executing 
agencies struggle to comply with. Therefore, the response is usually ad hoc and reactive. Tasks 
are outsourced to consultants while the executing agencies lack sufficient in-house technical 
expertise and systems to ensure safeguard compliance. Further, the government system has no 
positions or service structure for social safeguards. 
 
6.  During  project  preparation,  insufficient  attention  is  paid  to  project  implementation. 
Safeguards  are  not  considered  integral  to  effective  project  delivery.  Improved  coordination 
between design, contract bidding, award of civil works, and safeguards implementation is key to 
ensuring  project  implementation  complies  with  safeguards.  Safeguards  monitoring  is  not 
required under national systems, and this leads to poor compliance with loan covenants. In 
addition,  unlike  elsewhere  in  the  region,  civil  society  engagement  in  addressing  social 
safeguards issues is limited. 
 
7.  Implementation delays due to poor safeguard compliance. One of the key reasons 
for implementation delays in ADB-financed projects in Pakistan is the quality of resettlement 
plans and implementation. Pakistan applies the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 (LAA) for land 
acquisition for public purpose and for companies. The LAA is not accompanied by rules and 
regulations; each province interprets and implements the act according to its own systems 
through the respective BORs. The LAA is a complex law which only addresses land acquisition 
and is not intended to address adverse social impacts or deal with large-scale relocation and 
social development. Systemic weakness, lack of transparency, communication, resources, poor 
governance, and lack of coordination with implementing partners, coupled with limited national 
capacity  on  safeguards,  result  in  lengthy  delays  affecting  project  preparation  and 
implementation. Lacking direct responsibility for land acquisition, the executing agencies have 
limited coordination with the BORs, which exacerbates the problem and increases the risk of 
noncompliance. 
 
8.  Capacity development for safeguards in Pakistan requires long-term investment by the 
government as well as development partners. ADB and other development partners in the 
country are addressing some of the systemic issues related to land management, capacity 
development, and improved legal frameworks. However, there are still gaps at the operational 
and institutional levels for short- (including interpretation of the current legal framework) and 
medium-term gains.  
 
9.  Efforts to strengthen the capacities of executing agencies through short-term training 
and  close  supervision  by  ADB’s  Pakistan  Resident  Mission  have  resulted  in  incremental 
improvements. Current resident mission staff resources are inadequate to provide the level of

$1,050.7 million and for disbursement $722.5 million. 
5  The Pakistan Environment Protection Act (1997) is sufficient for addressing environment safeguards.

3 
support required to significantly improve executing agencies’ safeguards management. The 
ongoing  TA  for  the  Flood  Emergency  Reconstruction  Project6 demonstrates  the  benefit  of 
technical  support  to  executing  agencies  by  providing  consultants  for  both  preparation  and 
implementation. Even with this support, timely and efficient delivery remains a major challenge. 
Practical approaches to streamlining and coordinating safeguards need to be developed and 
integrated into business operations through standard operating procedures (SOPs) and tools to 
ensure  a  structured  process  of  screening  for  safeguard  risk.  Until  national  and  provincial 
legislation is developed, commitment to and ownership of safeguards by the executing agencies 
need to be enhanced. 
  
10.  National Highways Authority. The NHA established the Environment, Afforestation, 
Land and Social Safeguard Unit in 2007 at the headquarters in Islamabad, but there was no 
resettlement specialist. Staff resources in the environment section are better, with a director of 
environment and three staff members. However, four regional assistant director positions for 
environment remain vacant; similar positions for social safeguards are not available. The focus 
of the unit is on expeditious land acquisition and not on mitigating adverse social impacts. The 
NHA  has  52  ongoing  projects  across  Pakistan.  Staff  resources  in  the  Environment, 
Afforestation, Land and Social Safeguard Unit are insufficient and staff lack the skill to manage 
both domestically and externally financed projects. Staff designated to work on resettlement are 
legal experts with exposure and training on safeguards obtained by working on externally 
financed projects. Safeguards preparation is outsourced to large engineering firms with limited 
safeguards capacity. The combined effect of the NHA’s weak capacity and outsourcing to 
engineering  firms  is  poor  compliance  both  at  the  preparation  and  implementation  levels. 
Institutional support and enhanced capacity is necessary if the NHA is to respond effectively to 
social safeguards issues. 
 
11.  Water and Power Development Authority. The WAPDA is responsible for developing 
multipurpose water resources projects. Since the Ghazi Barotha project was completed in 2002, 
no new hydropower projects have been built. According to the Report of the Water Sector Task 
Force,7 the Tarbela project (officially completed in 1976 with funding from the World Bank) is still 
“plagued” by unsettled land compensation issues and uncertainty about numbers of displaced 
households. Pakistan faces a critical situation with regard to water storage and energy. Under 
the WAPDA’s vision 2025, eight priority projects for major dams at an estimated cost of $28.7 
billion are identified. The report further points out that there is “much confusion” in Pakistan 
about benefit sharing, essentially paying special attention to those who “pay the price” in terms 
of giving up their lands and are resettled. Large-scale projects typically entail the resettlement of 
several thousand households. In 2010, the WAPDA established the LARU, which has had a 
high staff turnover. The WAPDA Environment Cell was established in 1987; however, it is not 
adequately integrated into the business operations. The principal challenge for the WAPDA in 
undertaking  major  resettlement  programs  is  the  limited  pool  of  expertise  and  experienced 
specialists  in  the  LARU  and  in  Pakistan  in general.  Even  with  experienced  experts,  large 
resettlement programs require several full-time experts to be fully engaged in preparing and 
supervising  implementation.  Capacity  and  systems  for  internal  monitoring  of  large-scale 
resettlement and environment performance are yet to be established. The model for project 
development  requires  a  shift  in  thinking  where  design,  civil  works,  and  safeguards  are 
effectively coordinated and projects are designed to be environmentally and socially sound.

12.  BOR staff and engineering and management staff from the executing agencies will be 
included in key TA activities. A degree of institutional restructuring will be required to ensure the 
environment and social safeguard units are effectively incorporated into each agency’s structure. 
Tools for safeguards screening will be prepared to ensure a structured process for safeguards 
management.  Resettlement  policies  for  each  agency  will  be  developed.  Coordination  with 
multiple agencies will be supported, leading to development of procedures for interaction with 
key stakeholders. The TA approach is to work directly with the NHA and WAPDA and jointly 
develop work plans to ensure ownership of and commitment to the expected changes resulting 
from the TA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The  impact  of  the  TA  is  enhanced  safeguards  management  for  transport  projects 
executed by the NHA and water and power development projects executed by the WAPDA. The 
outcome of the TA is a safeguards management system established in each agency. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  Output 1: Legal, institutional, and capacity assessment report completed. The TA 
will support the preparation of an assessment of internal mechanisms for incorporating both 
environmental and social safeguards in the executing agencies’ business operations. SOPs and 
tools will be developed to support the integration of safeguards, as will tools to enable a uniform 
and structured process for safeguards risk assessment. Effort will be required to ensure these 
changes  are  incorporated  through  official  instructions.  The  analysis  will  be  based  on  staff 
interviews, review of existing SOPs, national and provincial acts and policies, and workshops 
with relevant staff in each organization. Lack of political will and management changes may 
affect the final approval of the SOPs. 
 
15.  Output  2:  Policy  on  resettlement  and  operations  framework  on  safeguards 
management developed. Stakeholder workshops will be held and the WAPDA resettlement 
policy  finalized;  the  NHA  has  no  resettlement  policy.  A  draft  policy  will  be  prepared  and 
stakeholder consultations held. Board approval will be sought for the final policies. Review of 
existing resettlement policies internationally, nationally, and within each organization will be 
conducted when developing the policies. Change in management and vested interests may 
pose a risk to final approval of the policies.  
 
16.  Output  3:  Advisory  service  provided  to  environment  and  social  units  in  the 
National Highways Authority and Water and Power Development Authority. Hands on 
capacity development will be provided to establish a complement of core safeguard staff in each 
agency.  Further,  the  TA  will  support  interpretation  of  laws  and  policies  and  recommend 
approaches  to  establish  transparent  mechanisms  for  achieving  replacement  cost  for 
compensation. At least two resettlement plans in each agency will be selected for review and 
improvement. Training will include key partner agencies such as the BORs and will include 
problem-solving workshops, project site visits, and visits to external projects and agencies to 
learn from their experience. Security concerns may prevent appropriate site visits in-country. 
 
17.  Output  4:  Technical  skills  of  Water  and  Power  Development  Authority  staff 
strengthened. The WAPDA resettlement unit was established in 2010. The environment cell is

5 
not adequately integrated within the organization. The LARU is relatively new and staff lack 
resettlement  experience.  Capacity  development  support  will  focus  on  problem-solving 
workshops and engagement with key partner agencies, including external experts. At least two 
resettlement plans with significant impacts will be selected for review. The consultants will 
support  the  team  to  enhance  the  plans  and  think  through  planning,  implementation,  and 
supervision of resettlement. External learning will be provided through visits to projects in the 
region. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $612,000, of which $550,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, space for workshops, and 
other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  The NHA and WAPDA are the executing agencies for the TA. The resident mission’s 
Safeguards  Unit  will  be  responsible  for  implementing  the  TA  and  consultant  recruitment, 
provision of information, reporting, and support to consultants where required in oversight, 
monitoring, and evaluation. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010 as amended from time to time), and the 
consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The consultants will be located in the offices of the NHA, 
WAPDA, and the resident mission depending on the activities being undertaken at different 
times. The TA will be implemented over 18 months, commencing in December 2012, and will be 
completed in May 2014. 
 
20.  Staff in the units will work closely with the consultants to implement the TA. Staff will 
identify workshop participants, support the consultants to identify core issues for discussion, and 
jointly develop the agenda.  
 
21.  The  TA  consultants  will  represent  multiple  disciplines  and  work  simultaneously  on 
different activities. Except for the international resettlement expert, all experts will contribute to 
the institutional analysis. Expert input includes an institutional specialist (12 person-months), a 
legal specialist (6 person-months), national resettlement specialists (32 person-months, one 
team leader), a grievance management specialist (6 person-months), management information 
system  specialists  (24  person-months),  a  monitoring  and  evaluation  specialist  (12  person-
months), a communication specialist (6 person-months), an environment specialist (3 person-
months),  and  an  international  resettlement  specialist  (4  person-months).  Recruitment  of 
consultants will be based on individual consultant selection because of the limited period of the 
TA and the varied and specialized skills and experience required. The specialists will be located 
in Islamabad and Lahore. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
22.  The TA outputs will be disseminated through the resident mission website and the 
website of each agency. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $550,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for Capacity Building for Enhanced Safeguards Management, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  objective  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  to  support  improved  safeguards 
management in the National Highways Authority (NHA) and the Water and Power Development 
Authority (WAPDA) in four main areas: (i) legal, institutional, and capacity analysis to identify 
key issues that need to be addressed for improved safeguards management; (ii) policy and 
operations  framework  on  safeguards  management  (environment,  land  acquisition,  and 
resettlement); (iii) advisory service provided to environment and social units in the NHA and 
WAPDA; and (iv) strengthening of technical skills of NHA and WAPDA staff. 
 
2.  Resettlement specialist and team leader (national, 16 person-months). The specialist 
will 
(i)  be responsible for coordinating and supervising consultants and all activities 
under  the  TA  to  be  implemented  in  the  NHA  and  WAPDA  and  submitting 
quarterly progress reports; 
(ii)  work under the overall guidance of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Pakistan 
Resident Mission to undertake the key TA activities related to resettlement; 
(iii)  prepare a time-bound work program that reflects the TA outputs; 
(iv)  support the institutional specialist and contribute to the analysis; based on the 
institutional assessment, work with the team and executing agency counterparts 
to develop standard operating procedures (SOPs) for social safeguards in both 
the NHA and WAPDA; 
(v)  with  the  WAPDA,  develop  mechanisms  for  achieving  consent  and  broad 
community support for project development by tribal groups; 
(vi)  review coordination of safeguards with civil works; 
(vii)  coordinate  with  the  executing  agencies  to  ensure  the  SOPs  and  tools  are 
approved and instructions issued by the relevant authorities; 
(viii)  based on the legal and institutional assessment and SOPs, develop a focused 
program for capacity development; in coordination with the executing agencies, 
develop operationally relevant orientation and sensitization programs on social 
safeguards for staff, including management staff, in the executing agencies; 
(ix)  organize problem-solving workshops with counterpart staff from the executing 
agencies; 
(x)  on  completion  of  workshops,  document,  review,  and  develop  a  typology  of 
activities  and  impacts  for  each  agency,  with  a  simple  guidance  tool  for 
addressing  safeguards;  develop  a  program  for  field  visits  including  external 
training programs; support the international specialist in drafting the resettlement 
policies for both executing agencies and holding stakeholder workshops; 
(xi)  support the team and executing agencies in developing the tools and systems, 
communications, information disclosure, management information system (MIS), 
grievance management, and monitoring and evaluation; 
(xii)  monitor progress of TA activities and prepare quarterly progress reports; 
(xiii)  coordinate and consult with other donor partners implementing safeguards; 
(xiv)  based on the diagnostics and work undertaken, recommend changes required for 
developing national and provincial policy; and 
(xv)  ensure disclosure of all reports on NHA, WAPDA, and ADB websites. 
 
3.  The specialist will have at least a master’s degree in the social sciences or similar field 
with at least 8–10 years work experience in resettlement, and experience working as a team 
leader, preferably on projects funded by international financial institutions.

Appendix 3  11 
4.  The specialist will deliver an individual and overall work program for the TA, the draft 
resettlement  policy  for  the  NHA,  the  final  resettlement  policy  for  the  WAPDA,  workshop 
completion reports, and a TA completion report. The specialist will work in Islamabad and 
Lahore from January 2013 to May 2014. 
 
5.  Legal specialist (national, 6 person-months). The specialist will 
(i)  identify  current  practices  within  the  executing  agencies  for  analyzing  the 
respective legal provisions applicable to the projects at national and provincial 
levels; 
(ii)  in consultation with the executing agencies’ land and legal experts, carry out a 
review of each province's land acquisition act, rules, and regulations and prepare 
an analysis which interprets the law, rules, and regulations in each province; 
(iii)  undertake a compatibility analysis of each province's land law and practice with 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) (involuntary resettlement principles) 
and provide recommendations on gap-filling measures that may be undertaken 
by the NHA and WAPDA; 
(iv)  consult with the respective boards of revenue to validate the report’s findings and 
recommendations; 
(v)  prepare a separate report identifying any other existing legal provisions, both 
national and provincial, that provide support for implementing ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  and  identify  which  instrument,  the  provision,  and  relevant 
interpretation; and 
(vi)  review legal provisions or identify mechanisms that enable replacement-value 
payment of compensation and make appropriate recommendations. 
 
6.  The specialist will have at least a master’s degree in law and familiarity with matters 
related to land acquisition, and work experience dealing with land acquisition or related tasks. 
 
7.  The specialist will deliver a work plan, reports on national and provincial safeguards-
related legislation, and an assignment completion report. The specialist will work intermittently in 
Islamabad and Lahore from January 2013 to May 2014. 
 
8.  Resettlement specialist (national, 16 person-months). The specialist will 
(i)  assist the team leader in implementing the TA; 
(ii)  support the TA activities dedicated to NHA capacity development; 
(iii)  contribute to the institutional analysis and support the institutional specialist in 
completing the report; 
(iv)  prepare  and  support  capacity  development  of  the  NHA  (Environment, 
Afforestation, Land and Social Safeguard Unit), specifically focusing on advisory 
support for project review, preparation of monitoring reports, and field visits to 
project sites; 
(v)  support the international resettlement specialist in drafting resettlement policies; 
(vi)  facilitate engagement between the NHA and the boards of revenue, including 
participation in brainstorming sessions and discussion workshops; and 
(vii)  review coordination of safeguards with civil works. 
 
9.  The specialist will have at least a master’s degree in social science or similar field, at 
least  5–10  years  experience  working  on  resettlement  familiarity,  and  work  experience  on 
projects financed by international financial institutions.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
10.  The specialist will deliver a work plan, and inputs for TA completion and workshop 
completion reports. The specialist will work in Islamabad and Lahore from January 2013 to May 
2014. 
 
11.  Environment specialist (national, 3 person-months). The specialist will contribute to the 
institutional analysis. In coordination with the team and the executing agencies, the specialist 
will develop the SOPs for enhancing safeguards management in each agency, and will also 
prepare a time-bound action plan for improving environmental management in each agency. 
 
12.  The specialist will have at least a master’s degree in environmental sciences with at 
least 10 years experience in preparing initial environmental examinations and environmental 
impact  assessments,  and  experience  in  monitoring  environmental  management  plans  and 
supervision of environment performance. 
 
13.  The specialist will deliver a work plan, workshop completion reports, and an assignment 
completion report. The specialist will work intermittently in Islamabad and Lahore from July 2013 
to January 2014. 
 
14.  Grievance management specialist (national, 6 person-months). The specialist will 
(i)  develop gender-sensitive systems, tools, and protocols to improve efficiency of 
grievance management; 
(ii)  develop a work program for grievance actions and support executing agencies to 
implement  the  work  plan,  including  establishing  the  systems,  and  improve 
reporting and outreach where required; and 
(iii)  report on the progress of grievance action plans on selected projects. 
 
15.  The  specialist  will  have  at  least  a  master’s  degree  in  communications  or  relevant 
discipline and demonstrated experience in designing and implementing grievance management 
systems and customer services management. 
 
16.  The specialist will deliver a work plan, a report on the implementation of grievance action 
plans, and an assignment completion report. The specialist will work intermittently in Islamabad 
and Lahore from January 2013 to December 2013. 
 
17.  Institutional specialist (national, 12 person-months). The specialist will 
(i)  carry out an institutional analysis of the NHA and ADB for managing safeguards, 
(ii)  review available data and collect primary data to obtain first-hand information of 
key problem areas in their institutional set up that hamper effective management 
of safeguards, 
(iii)  prepare a report and recommendations identifying key institutional gaps that 
need to be addressed to ensure effective institutionalization of safeguards, and 
(iv)  develop relevant SOPs and protocols for mainstreaming safeguards. 
 
18.  The specialist will have at least a master’s degree in management studies or relevant 
discipline and at least 5 years experience in conducting institutional analysis and restructuring 
large organizations. 
 
19.  The specialist will deliver a work plan, an institutional analysis report for the NHA and 
WAPDA, quarterly progress reports, and an assignment completion report. The specialist will 
work intermittently in Islamabad and Lahore from January 2013 to May 2014.

Appendix 3  13 
 
20.  Monitoring and evaluation specialist (national, 12 person-months). The specialist will 
(i)  review current procedures and tools for internal monitoring and identify gaps; 
(ii)  develop tools for environmental and social safeguards monitoring and reporting; 
(iii)  work with the MIS specialist and data operators to establish a monitoring system, 
and provide capacity development by working with the executing agencies on 
monitoring reports; and 
(iv)  provide support for achieving the TA outputs. 
 
21.  The specialist will have at least a master’s degree in evaluation studies or relevant 
discipline  and  at  least  5  years  experience  in  operations  research  and  designing  and 
implementing monitoring and evaluation of development projects. 
 
22.  The specialist will deliver a work plan, quarterly progress reports, and an assignment 
completion report. The specialist will work intermittently in Islamabad and Lahore from February 
2013 to May 2014. 
 
23.  Communications specialist (national, 6 person-months). The specialist will 
(i)  identify  gaps  and  support  the  executing  agencies  in  developing  an  effective 
communications strategy; 
(ii)  develop effective communication tools that are culturally articulated, and develop 
systems  to  ensure  the  executing  agencies  establish  systems  for  routine 
information sharing and disclosure; 
(iii)  conduct  field-based  communications  training  by  executing  multiple 
communication tools in projects under preparation; and 
(iv)  support the institutional specialist in communications strategies of the executing 
agencies. 
 
24.  The specialist will have a master’s degree in communications with at least 5 years 
experience in developing and disseminating information through multiple means to both literate 
and non literate groups and varied target groups.  
 
25.  The  specialist  will  deliver  a  work  plan  and  an  assignment  completion  report.  The 
specialist will work in Islamabad and Lahore from January 2013 to July 2013. 
 
26.  Management information system specialists (2 national, 24 person–months). The 
specialists will 
(i)  review  the  executing  agencies’  capacity  for  maintaining  an  MIS;  with  the 
monitoring and evaluation specialist, develop an MIS to enable the executing 
agencies to establish a computerized database of resettlement; 
(ii)  provide guidance to the executing agencies and the data operators to input 
information and conduct cross-analyses and report generation; and 
(iii)  support the institutional specialist in conducting the institutional analysis, and 
prepare quarterly progress reports. 
 
27.  The specialists will have at least a master’s degree in information sciences or relevant 
discipline and demonstrated experience of at least 5 years in developing and managing MIS.

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
28.  The specialists will deliver a work plan, quarterly progress reports, and an assignment 
completion report. The specialists will work in Islamabad and Lahore from February 2013 to 
February 2014. 
 
29.  Resettlement specialist (international, 4 person-months, intermittent). The specialist 
will 
(i)  review  the  draft  resettlement  policy  of  the  WAPDA  and  provide  support  to 
enhance the policy to meet international best practice standards, 
(ii)  consult with key stakeholders during policy formulation, 
(iii)  coordinate with the national resettlement specialists and prepare the draft policy 
on resettlement in the NHA, 
(iv)  conduct site visits as relevant to inform the development of the policies, and 
(v)  participate in at least one of the consultation workshops held by each institution. 
 
30.  The specialist will have at least a master’s degree in social sciences or similar field, and 
at least 10 years international work experience in resettlement and policy development. 
 
31.  The  specialist  will  deliver  a  work  plan,  two  policy  and  operations  frameworks  on 
safeguards management in both agencies, and an assignment completion report. The specialist 
will work intermittently in Islamabad and Lahore from March 2013 to May 2014.
